snippet: Some of the nation’s largest wireless phone companies, like AT&T and Verizon, use a process called throttling to slow down customers who exceed data limits — even if they have unlimited data plans.
abstract: Some of the nation’s largest wireless phone companies, like AT&T and Verizon, use a process called throttling to slow down customers who exceed data limits--even if they have unlimited data plans; firms say they are trying to find a fair way to manage the swelling demand for mobile data, but consumers are feeling cheated and suspect some carriers are trying to lure them into higher-cost plans.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s largest wireless phone companies, like AT&T and Verizon, use a process called throttling to slow down customers who exceed data limits — even if they have unlimited data plans.

headline.seo: AT&T Revises Limits for Unlimited Data Users
headline.main: Revising the Limits for the Unlimited
